resources.string: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit.
Crown to rump length 1 (cm) (If ≥8 and > 14 wks)
Crown to rump length 2 (cm) (If ≥8 and > 14 wks)
Crown to rump length 3 (cm) (If ≥8 and > 14 wks)
Gestational age at ultrasound in COMPLETED WEEKS
Gestational age at ultrasound in EXTRA DAYS over completed weeks
Any other important finding relevant for the health of the mother or the fetus (e.g. no heartbeat or other reasons for referral). Specify.
Has the woman mother given her consent to be enrolled in the study?
If ACT cohort, has mother given consent to access ACT study data?
If child’s age > 41 months DO NOT proceed
Which language is (name of the child) learning to speak at home?
Is this the same language as the GSED translation?
Are you (name of the child)’s primary caregiver?
What is your relationship to (name of the child)?
Has your child been diagnosed with a severe or chronic medical condition for which you visit regularly a doctor or a facility (including congenital birth defect, or chronic heart disease)?
Do you have any concerns that your child’s development is different than other children of the same age?
If yes, which of the below concerns do you have?
Compared with children of the same age, does the child have difficulty moving/walking?
Compared with children of the same age, does the child have difficulty learning to do new things?
Has the child ever suffered from prolonged (>10 min) seizures or recurrent convulsions (more than 2 or 3 in a day on more than one occasion)? This does not include febrile convulsions
Compared with other children does the child have difficulty seeing, either in the daytime or at night?
Compared with other children does the child have difficulty hearing?
Does the child have any special needs or disabilities that you know of
Is the child unwell/ill today or has s/he been in the last 5 days?
If yes, which of these signs does/did the child have?
Very sleepy/tired/without energy, only moving when stimulated and not themselves
Which measure was done - child’s length or height?
Child’s height/length (in cm) reader 1 first reading
Child’s height/length (in cm) reader 2 first reading
Child’s height/length (in cm) reader 1 second reading
Child’s height/length (in cm) reader 2 second reading
Child’s height/length (in cm) reader 1 third reading
Child’s height/length (in cm) reader 2 third reading
Child’s weight (in grams) reader 1 first reading
Child’s weight (in grams) reader 2 first reading
Child’s weight (in grams) reader 1 second reading
Child’s weight (in grams) reader 2 second reading
Child’s weight (in grams) reader 1 third reading
Child’s weight (in grams) reader 2 third reading
How many years of formal schooling did you complete?
if < 5 years EXCLUDE from healthy sample
if < 2500 grams EXCLUDE from healthy sample
If < 37 completed weeks (259 days) OR ³ 42 completed weeks (294 days) EXCLUDE from healthy sample
Undernutrition (weight for age, length for age, OR weight for height Z score > –2 on the WHO Child Growth Standards) (report from anthropometric assessment)
if yes EXCLUDE from healthy sample
Was the child hospitalized longer than usual at birth (e.g. due to asphyxia OR neonatal sepsis)?
if yes EXCLUDE from healthy sample
Family speaks to the child in different language than GSED translated instrument
Child unwell at the time of assessment
Known severe neurodevelopmental disorder/ disability (that is severe cerebral palsy, severe visual problems, seizures, severe hearing impairment)
Child is eligible for (tick one please)
Is this assessment to be included as part of test-retest reliability?
Is this assessment to be included as part of inter-rater reliability?
If yes, has the caregiver given consent to video recording?
Is this assessment to be included as part of concurrent validity with BSID III?
How many pregnancies have you had?
How many deliveries of a live child have you had?
How many living children do you have?
Did you have any prolonged (>3 days) high fever during your pregnancy?
Were you admitted to sleep at a facility because of the any symptoms you experienced during pregnancy?
Did you take any medication regularly during pregnancy?
Have you ever used any recreational drugs?
If yes, when did you use the drug?
If yes, which recreational drug do/did you use?
What type of delivery did you have?
How much time before delivery of the baby did the waters break?
NA (broke during delivery/did not break before C-section)
How much time before delivery of the baby did the woman’s labour pains start?
Would you rate your health as being good overall?
Do you have any diagnosed chronic conditions for which you visit a doctor or health facility on a regular basis?
Who is the head of your household?
How many years of schooling did the child’s father or head of the household complete?
What is the current occupation of the father or the head of the household?
If occupation of child’s father or head of the household is "other", specify
Is child’s father currently living with the family?
What is the main source of drinking water for members of your household?
Tube well or borehole or hand pump
Surface Water (River / Dam / Lake / Pond / Stream / Canal)
If source of water is "other", specify
What kind of toilet facility do you usually use?
No toilet facility (uses open space or field)
What is the religion of the head of the household?
What is the ethnic group of the head of the household?
Each site to decide possible outcomes
What type of fuel does the household mainly use for cooking
How many rooms in your house (including the kitchen) are used for sleeping
How many persons slept in the house last night?
Do you own or rent the house you live in, or do you have another type of arrangement, such as “perching”?
Does this household own any land?
Does anyone in the household own:
Is there electrical supply at home?
Materials used in the construction of the house (observe): H45
Does your child cry when he/she is hungry, wet, tired, or wants to be held?
Does your child look at and focus on objects in front of him/her?
Does your child grasp your finger if you touch her hand?
Does your child make sounds other than crying?
When your child is on his/her stomach, can he/she turn his/her head to the side?
When your child is on his/her stomach, can he/she hold his/her head up off the ground?
Can your child roll from his/her back to stomach or stomach to his/her side?
Does your child make noise or gesture to get your attention?
Does your child hold his/her hands in fists all the time?
While your child is on his/her back, can he/she bring his/her hands together?
Does your child sometimes suck his/her thumb or fingers?
Does your child try to move his/her head (or eyes) to follow an object or person?
When lying on his/her back, does your child move his/her arms and legs?
Does your child look at a person when that person starts talking or making noise?
Does your child smile when you smile or talk with him/her?
Does your child bring his/her hand to his/her mouth?
When you talk to your child, does he/she smile, make noises, or move arms, legs or trunk in response?
When you are about to pick up your child, does he/she act happy or excited?
Does your child look at your face when you speak to him/her?
Does your child stop crying or calm down when you come to the room after being out of sight, or when you pick him or her up?
Does your child turn his/her head towards your voice or some noise?
Does your child make sounds when LOOKING at toys or people (not crying)?
Can your child hold his/her head steady for at least a few seconds, without it flopping to the side?
Does your child move excitedly, kick legs, move arms or trunk, or make coo noises when a known person enters the room or speaks to them? [Removed "smile"]
Does your child grasp onto a small object (e.g., your finger, a spoon) when put in his/her hand?
Does your child make single sounds like "buh" or "duh" or "muh"?
Does your child try to reach for objects that are in front of him/her by extending one or both arms?
When he/she is on his/her tummy, can your child hold his/her head straight up, looking around for more than a few seconds? He/she can rest on his/her arms while doing this.

If you play a game with your child, does he/she respond with interest? For example, if you play peek-a-boo, pat-a-cake, wave bye-bye, etc. does your child smile, widen their eyes, kick or move arms or vocalize?
Does your child smile or become excited when seeing someone familiar?
Does your child recognize you or other family members (e.g., smile when they enter a room or move toward them)?
Can your child reach for AND HOLD an object, at least for a few seconds?
When you put your child on the floor, can she lean on her hands while sitting? (If she already sits up straight without leaning on her hands, mark \'yes\' for this item.)
When held in a sitting position, can the child hold his/her head steady and straight?
Does your child show interest in new objects that are put in front of him/her by reaching out for them?
Can your child roll from his/her back to stomach, or stomach to back, on his/her own?
Can your child pick up a small object (e.g., a small toy or small stone) using just one hand?
When lying on his/her stomach, can your child hold his/her head and chest off the ground using only his/her hands and arms for support?
Can your child eat food from your fingers or off a spoon you hold?
When lying on his/her back, does the child grab his/her feet?
Can your child sit with support, either leaning against something (furniture or person), or by leaning forward on his or her hands?
If an object falls to the ground out of view, does your child look for it?
Does your child play by tapping an object on the ground or a table?
Does your child intentionally move or change his/her position to get objects that are out of reach?
Can your child hold him/herself in a sitting position without help or support for longer than a few seconds?
Is your child interested when he/she sees other children playing? Does she or he watch, smile, or look excited?
Does your child bang objects together, or bang an object on the table or on the ground?
Can your child pass a small object from one hand to the other?
Can your child pick up a small object (e.g., a piece of food, small toy or small stone) with just his/her thumb and one finger?
Does the child look for an object of interest when it is removed from sight or hidden from him/her (e.g., put under a cover, behind another object)?
While holding onto furniture, does your child bend down and pick up a small object from the floor and then return to a standing position?
Can your child maintain a standing position while holding on to a person or object (e.g., wall or furniture)?
Can your child pull themselves up from the floor while holding onto something? For example, can they pull themselves up using a chair, a person, or some other object?
Does your child make two similar sounds together like baba, mumu, pepe, di (single consonant vowel combinations)?
While holding onto furniture, does your child squat with control (without falling or flopping down)?
Can your child pick up and drop a small object (e.g., a small toy or small stone) into a bucket or bowl while sitting?
Can your child walk several steps while holding on to a person or object (e.g., wall or furniture)?
Does your child stop what he/she is doing when you say “Stop!” even if just for a second?
Can your child stand up without holding onto anything, even if just for a few seconds?
Can your child maintain a standing position on his/her own, without holding on or receiving support?
Can your child make any light marks on paper or in dirt with a crayon or a stick?
Can your child pick up small bits of food and feed him/her-self using his/her hand?
Can your child climb onto an object (rock, porch, step, chair, bed, low table, etc.)?
Can your child take several steps (3-5) forward without holding onto any person or object, even if they fall down immediately afterward?
Can your child move around by walking, rather than by crawling on his hands and knees?
Does your child make a gesture to indicate “No” (e.g., shaking head)?
Can your child stand up from sitting by himself and take several steps forward?
Can your child bend down or squat to pick up an object from the floor and then stand up again, without help from a person or object?
Can your child make a scribble on paper, or in dirt, in a back and forth manner? For example, can he or she move the pen or pencil or stick back and forth?
Does your child follow a simple spoken command or direction without you making a gesture?
Does your child fetch something when asked?
Can your child drink from an open cup without help?
While standing, can your child purposefully throw the ball and not just drop it?
Can your child walk well, with coordination, without falling down often? With one foot in front of the other (rather than shifting weight side to side, stiff- legged)?
Does your child put his/her hands out to have them washed?
Can your child stack at least two objects on top of each other, such as bottle tops, blocks, stones, etc.?
Can your child kick a ball or other round object forward using his/her foot?
While standing, can your child kick a ball by swinging his/her leg forward?
Can your child follow directions with more than one step? For example, \'Go to the kitchen and bring me a spoon\'?
Even if your child is unable to do singing games, does he/she enjoy them and want to be a part of them?
Can your child stack three or more small objects (e.g., blocks, cups, bottle caps) on top of each other?
Can your child run well, without falling or bumping into objects?
Can your child greet people either by giving his/her hand or saying “hello”?
Does your child share with others (e.g., food)?
Can your child dry hands by herself/himself after you have washed them?
Is your child able to go poo or pee without having accidents (wetting or soiling themselves)?
Can your child say five or more separate words (e.g., names like "Mama" or objects like "ball")?
Can your child speak using short sentences of two words that go together (e.g., \'Mama go\' or \'Dada eat\'?
Can your child wash hands by him/herself?
Can your child ask for something (e.g., food, water) by name when he/she wants it?
Can your child break off pieces of food and feed them to him/her-self?
Does your child show independence (e.g., wants to go and visit a friend’s house)?
Can your child correctly name at least one family member other than mom and dad (e.g., name of brother, sister, aunt, uncle)?
When looking at pictures, if you say to your child "what is this?", can they say the name of the object that you point to?
Can your child identify at least seven objects? For example, when you ask \'where is the ball/spoon/cup/cloth/door/plate/bucket etc.\' does your child look at or point to (or even name) the objects?
Can your child walk on an uneven surface (e.g., a bumpy or steep road) without falling?
Can your child name at least two body parts (e.g., arm, eye, or nose)?
If you show your child an object he/she knows well (e.g., a cup or animal), can he/she consistently name it?
Does your child usually communicate with words what he/she wants in a way that is understandable to others?
Can your child draw a straight line?
Can your child remove an item of clothing (e.g., take off his/her shirt)?
Can your child say ten or more separate words (e.g., names like "Mama" or objects like "ball")?
Can your child jump with both feet leaving the ground?
Can your child sing a short song or repeat parts of a rhyme from memory by him/herself?
Can your child tell you or someone familiar his/her own name [nickname] when asked to?
Can your child put on at least one piece of clothing by himself?
Can your child say 15 or more words in addition to "Mama" and "Dada"?
Can your child unscrew the lid from a bottle or jar?
Can your child speak using sentences of three or more words that go together (e.g., "I want water" or "The house is big")?
Can your child correctly use any of the words "I," "you," "she," or "he" (e.g., "I go to store," or "He eats rice")?
Does your child know the difference between the words "big" and "small"? For example, if you ask, "Give me the big spoon" can your child understand which one to give if there are two different sizes?
Can your child say what he/she likes or dislikes (e.g., "I like sweets")?
Can your child correctly ask questions using any of the words "what," "which," "where," or "who"?
Does your child pronounce most of his/her words correctly?
If you show your child two objects or people of different size, can he/she tell you which one is the big one and which is the small one?
Can your child count up to five objects (e.g., fingers, people)?
Can your child explain in words what common objects like a cup or chair are used for?
If you point to an object, can your child correctly use the words "on," "in," or "under" to describe where it is (e.g., "The cup is on the table" instead of "The cup is in the table.")
Does your child regularly use describing words such as "fast," "short," "hot," "fat," or "beautiful" correctly?
Can the child name at least one color (e.g., red, blue, yellow)?
Does your child know to keep quiet at important events or ceremonies?
Does your child ask "why" questions (e.g., "Why are you tall?")?
Can your child tell you when he/she is happy, angry, or sad?
If you ask your child to give you three objects (e.g., stones, beans), does the child give you the correct amount?
Can your child tell a story?
Can your child tell you when others are happy, angry, or sad?
Can your child dress him/herself completely (except for shoelaces, buttons and zippers)?
Does your child help out around the house with simple chores, even if he/she doesn\'t do them well?
Does your child understand the term \'longest\'? For example, if you ask them to choose \'which is the longest of 3 objects?\' e.g. 3 spoons or sticks, would he/she be able to choose the longest?
Can the child fasten and unfasten buttons without help?
If you draw a circle can your child do it, just as you did?
Can your child go to the toilet by him/her-self?
Can your child stand on one foot WITHOUT any support for at least a few seconds?
Can your child say what others like or dislike (e.g., "Mama doesn't like fruit," Papa likes football)?
Does your child show respect around elders?
Can your child talk about things that have happened in the past using correct language (e.g., "Yesterday I played with my friend" or "Last week she went to the market")?
Can your child talk about things that will happen in the future using correct language (e.g., "Tomorrow he will attend school" or "Next week we will go to the market")?
Does your child intentionally try to hurt you or other familiar adults?
Does your child kick, bite, or hit other children?
Does your child kick, bite or hit familiar adults?
When a known adult asks your child to do something, does he/she usually comply?
Does your child repeatedly not follow rules?
Does your child intentionally destroy or act aggressively with objects?
Does your child get easily frustrated with everyday tasks?
Is your child generally irritable or fussy?
Is your child often impatient or unwilling to wait when you ask him/her to?
Does your child often have difficulty getting along with other children?
Does your child have difficulty taking turns when playing with others?
Does your child often lose their temper?
Is your child often restless and cannot stay still?
Does your child often have trouble paying attention?
Does your child cry or whine when he/she is made to wait for something he/she wants (e.g., toy or food)?
Is your child intentionally cruel to animals?
Is your child intentionally mean to other children?
Does your child often get nervous or tense?
Does your child hold on to you and has a hard time leaving your side?
Does your child have many fears or is easily scared?
Does your child often get worried or anxious?
Is your child often sad or unhappy?
Does the child often have extreme changes in emotions (e.g., quickly changing from very happy to very angry)?
Does the child often show panic or fear for no reason?
Does your child show little interest in things around him or her?
Does the child often refuse to play with other children?
Does the child become afraid around strangers, even when you\'re with him/her?
Does the child at times become extremely withdrawn (extremely introverted, lost, unreadable, unresponsive)?
Does the child almost always prefer to play alone, even when other children are present?
Does your child often have a hard time calming down on his or her own?
Does your child often have a hard time calming down even when you soothe him/her?
When upset, does your child get very still, freeze or does not move?
Does your child frequently act impulsively without thinking (e.g., running into the street without looking….generate appropriate examples)?
Does the child often cry for no reason (e.g., when he/she is not hungry or tired)?
Does your child repeatedly rock his/her head or body?
Does your child wake up more than two times at night and want your attention (e.g., cries, asks for you)?
Does the child often reject or turn away from affection (e.g., refuses or pulls away from hugs from well-known family members)?
Does your child display any strange behaviors? What?
Does the child become distressed (e.g., cries, screams) in response to loud sounds or bright lights?
Does the child have trouble falling asleep most nights?
Does your child eat too little?
Does your child refuse to eat foods that you think are healthy?
Does your child not seem hungry when it is time to eat?
Does your child eat only a few particles of food?
Does your child have an irregular eating pattern?
Does your child sleep less than other children of the same age?
Does your child have difficulty staying asleep?
Does your child have an irregular sleep schedule?
Does your child have difficulty falling asleep?
Does your child have difficulty falling asleep after waking at night?
Does your child have difficulty separating at bedtime?
Does your child seem angry or withdrawn when you have been separated?
Does your child ignore you or seem angry with you when you do not immediately respond to him/her?
Does your child often seem fussy or cry, and you are not able to console him/her?
Do you have any concerns about how your child behaves?
Do you have any concerns about how your child gets along with others?
Does your child resist looking you in the eye?
Does your child seem to look through or past people?
Does your child too often need help to fall asleep?
Does your child scream in their sleep and cannot be comforted?

During testing, observe whether the child responds to a person\'s voice. If you do not observe the behavior, stand beside the child so child can see you but is not looking at you. Call the child\'s name in a normal tone of voice. Score YES: Child clearly responds to the person\'s voice by startling, moving eyes, turning his or her head, changing activity level, changing facial expressions, or vocalizing. NO: Child shows no change in behavior in response to the person\'s voice.
Hold the child on his/her back and put your face about 30 cm (12 inches) above the child\'s face. Score YES: Child looks at you (fixates eyes on your face). NO: Child does not look at you.

During testing, observe the child to see how he or she responds to attention NOTE: why the change from observer in the original to caregiver?? from the caregiver, e.g., smiles, laughs, or vocalizes. If you do not note this behavior, ask caregiver to elicit the behavior. Examples of techniques to elicit smile: Caregiver can try snuggling with the child while speaking to him or her, varying vocal quality by changing pitch, loudness, or duration of utterances; gently patting the child while speaking to or singing softly to him or her. Score YES if child smiles in response to the the caregiver. Score NO if child makes no response or cries

Stand behind the child and clap loudly. If no response, shake rattle. Rather than another item, substitute rattle with clicking sound. Credit YES: Child responds in any way e.g. a change in activity or expression or eye movement. NO: Child does not respond
Lifts head to 45 degrees on prone position*

Place the child on his/her tummy on a flat surface. Stand in front and call to child. Score: YES. Child lifts head so that face makes 45 degree angle with the surface for several seconds. Note that the child does not have to look at you - will likely be looking at the surface. No: Child does not lift head or lifts less than few seconds
Happy vocalizing or making sounds  not crying*

INCIDENTAL OBSERVATION: Listen and note if child makes sounds other than crying e.g. throaty sounds or sounds such as “uh” or “eh” or “a, a, a” or gurgling sounds. Any vocal sound rather than crying. IF NOT OBSERVED, ask caregiver to play or talk with child to try and elicit vocalizations. Score YES if child makes sounds as described.

USE BRIGHTLY COLORED BALL: Place the child on his/her back and hold a bright object above the child’s face at about 15 cms (6 inches). Move the object in an arc from one side to the other. Score YES: Child follow the bright object through a complete arc from left to right e.g. through 180 degrees. NO: Child does not follow object through complete arc.
Frolics alone, plays around moving body, kicking legs in a happy way*

INCIDENTAL OBSERVATION: Child frolics when lying on back. IF NOT OBSERVED, ask caregiver….Score YES: Child plays around with self, moving body and kicking legs happily. NO: Child does not move arms and legs. Question. Must move legs?
Frolics with caregiver (moves body in response to another person)*

INCIDENTAL OBSERVATION: Encourage caregiver to play with child while child is lying on back. Score YES: Child moves his or her body in response to being played with by caregiver. NO: Child does not move body
Pulls to sit with no head lag*

Put the child on his/her back on a flat surface.Hold the childs hands and pull the baby up to a sitting position. Score: YES. Childs head comes with the body and does not lag or fall behind while the body is being pulled up. If it does from early on, stop. NO: Child\'s head lags.

USES RATTLE: While the child is lying on his/her back or is being held by the caregiver, touch the back or tips of the childs fingers with the handle of the rattle. Score YES: Child grasps the rattle for a few seconds. Score NO: Child does not grasp rattle
Lifts head, shoulders and chest when prone*

Put the child on his/her stomach on a flat surface. Score YES: Child lifts HEAD and CHEST off the surface using arms for support so that he/she is looking ahead or even upwards. NO: Child does not lift head and chest off surface and look forward.

INCIDENTAL OBSERVATION: See if the child laughs out loud during testing. If you do not note this behavior, ask caregiver to elicit the behavior. Examples of techniques to elicit smile: Snuggling with the child while speaking to him or her, varying vocal quality by changing pitch, loudness, or duration of utterances; gently patting the child while speaking to or singing softly to him or her. Score YES: Child laughs or chuckles. Score NO: Child makes no noise or cries.
Recognizes or calms and quiets with caregivers/known family members*

INCIDENTAL OBSERVATION OR CAREGIVER REPORT: If child cries or fusses during test, observe if child stops crying or quiets when caregiver attends to child. If child does not cry or fuss, ask caregiver if child typically calms when caregiver attends. Score YES: Observe child calming in response to caregiver or caregiver reports child calming. NO: Child does not calm in response to caregiver or caregiver reports that child does not calm in response to caregiver.
Puts hands together in front of eyes or mouth*

Place the child on his/her back, put the child’s hands in front of the eyes to look at them. Credit. YES: Child keeps hands in front of eyes looking at them or brings hands to eyes or mouth spontaneously. Do not cradle the baby in the parent’s arms during this. NO. Child does not look at or play with hands or does not seem to recognize hands
